Award.AwardTitle: CNH2-S: Interactive Dynamics of Stream Restoration and Flood Resilience in a Changing Climate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Upper Mississippi River Basin has seen increasingly frequent flooding in recent years, a trend that will almost certainly worsen. Wisconsin’s Kickapoo River and Coon Creek watersheds have experienced at least three 100-year floods in the last decade, and there is an urgent need to understand how to address and adapt to this new reality. In response, this CNH2-S project brings together researchers from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and Indiana University with cross-disciplinary expertise in biophysical and social approaches to stream restoration and flooding. Working closely with local partners in the Kickapoo and Coon Creek watersheds, the research team will use interviews and online surveys with local decision-makers, land and water managers, and agricultural landowners to learn about changing attitudes towards stream restoration and to inform the development of new flood models that work from the level of an individual section of stream to an entire watershed. Those models will be refined through a series of interactive workshops, resulting in locally informed models. The project team’s emphasis on public engagement will allow them to analyze and promote workable and effective agricultural best management practices and flood prevention strategies that can contribute to local resilience planning in these rural and under-resourced communities, and offer a model for other communities faced with persistent flooding.

This CNH2-S project will ask four nested questions that interrogate the multi-scalar dynamic feedbacks between in-stream restoration practices, upland conservation measures, flood peaks, and community-level impacts of and responses to climate change: (1) How does more frequent and more intense flooding across the Upper Mississippi River Basin alter stream restoration practices in the study watersheds, linking or breaking the potential connection between restoration and resilience? (2) How do stream restoration practices, particularly changes in channel morphology, impact community-level climate vulnerability to flooding? (3) How do stream managers, flood decision makers, and landowners balance socio-environmental tradeoffs related to flood vulnerability and resilience across the reach and watershed scales? (4) Can iterative, multi-scalar hydrologic and hydraulic modeling be incorporated with qualitative and participatory approaches to support stakeholder-based flood resilience planning to enable social-ecological system (SES) transformations? The density of stream restoration projects in the Kickapoo and Coon Creek (WI) watersheds, coupled with long-term impacts and accelerating frequency of flood events and community interest in flood planning, will allow the research team to co-create knowledge with local partners that extends existing research in social-ecological systems (SES) resilience: heeding recent calls to offer empirical studies of community-level climate vulnerability and responses to climate change, while focusing on innovative linkages between restoration and resilience to consider new opportunities for SES transformations. The approach advances understandings of the complex responses of flood hydrology and hydraulics to multi-scalar flood management interventions, filling a significant gap by relating flood hydraulic and watershed hydrologic approaches to investigate how stream- floodplain restoration interacts and compares with upland practices to reduce flood peaks. This multi-scalar approach, with its grounding in stakeholder engagement mechanisms, offers a testable, methodologically innovative, partner-centered, resilience-focused systems approach to flood risk management that can advance resilience planning in the study watersheds and in other socio-environmental systems facing rapid and uncertain changes related to climate change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Upper Mississippi River Basin (UMRB) has seen increasingly frequent flooding, a trend that climate change will almost certainly worsen. Wisconsin's Kickapoo River and Coon Creek watersheds, in the UMRB's Driftless region, have experienced at least three 100-year-magnitude floods in the last decade, and climate forecasts predict this pattern will intensify. The worst of these floods, in August 2018, caused $29 million in damage to businesses, homes, and public infrastructure in Vernon County alone. Six years later, communities are still working to repair damaged infrastructure and sustain a public discussion about what flood resilience might look like; the major question is no longer whether the next catastrophic flood will happen, but how soon. This CNH2-S research project investigated the interactive dynamics of stream restoration and flood resilience in a changing climate in the Kickapoo and Coon Creek watersheds. Co-producing knowledge with long-time watershed partners, the project integrated qualitative interviews with iterative, multiscalar hydrologic and hydraulic modeling and sustained community participation to consider the roles of stream restoration and upland best management practices (BMPs) in a suite of flood resilience strategies in a changing climate. We asked how more frequent and intense flooding altered stream restoration practices; how changes in channel morphology impacted community-level climate vulnerability; how stream managers, flood decision makers, and landowners balanced social-ecological systems (SES) tradeoffs across scales; and whether iterative, multiscalar hydrologic and hydraulic modeling could be incorporated with qualitative, participatory approaches to support stakeholder-based flood resilience planning to enable SES transformations.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT
The density of restoration projects in study watersheds, coupled with long-term impacts and accelerating frequency of flood events and community interest in flood planning, allowed the research team to co-create knowledge with local partners that extended existing research in SES resilience: heeding recent calls to offer empirical studies of community-level climate vulnerability and responses to climate change, while focusing on innovative linkages between restoration and resilience to consider new opportunities for SES transformations. Our approach advanced understandings of the complex responses of flood hydrology and hydraulics to multi-scalar flood management interventions, filling a significant gap by relating flood hydraulic and watershed hydrologic approaches to investigate how stream-floodplain restoration interacts and compares with upland practices to reduce flood peaks. This multiscalar approach, with its grounding in stakeholder engagement mechanisms, offers a testable, methodologically innovative, partner-centered, resilience-focused systems approach to flood risk management. By offering an integrated and iterative approach to stakeholder-based modeling across scales; exploring new feedbacks between stream restoration and flooding in a region experiencing accelerated impacts of climate change; and leveraging existing datasets, models, and relationships with local partners, this action-oriented research advanced resilience planning in study watersheds and stands to contribute to other socio-environmental systems facing rapid and uncertain changes related to climate change. The research team published articles, chapters, and public documents from this work focused on mixed-methods interdisciplinary research, on potential harms from quick fix approaches to beaver-based restoration, on management disagreements about riparian vegetation management, on archival news analysis related to community flooding, and on community oral narratives related to flood impacts and the Coon Creek Watershed. Related work is under review and in progress, focused on stream fixing, non-structural flood management, and riparian vegetation.   

BROADER IMPACTS
The project trained cross-disciplinary undergraduate and graduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, and involved them in both research and community engagement. One graduate student trained on the project transitioned into a leadership role with one of our community partners upon graduation, and project PIs remain in close touch with county and non-profit partners. Another graduate student trained on the project re-entered the water resources engineering consulting industry with a stronger recognition of the need for meaningful community engagement and the strengths and limitations of hydrologic & hydraulic models. This project directly benefited community flood resilience planning in under-resourced and isolated rural counties, centering the work of local non-profits, decision-makers, and landowners. By testing an innovative approach to iterative, participatory modeling, and creating FloodScape, a new responsive tool for flood decision-making, the project offered a proof of concept for future researchers and decision-makers working towards SES transformations in the face of community-level climate vulnerability. The project influenced community-level decisions about flood response as part of a federal PLAN-Environmental Impact Statement process related to dam breaches across the watershed. The work also pointed out important gaps to be addressed in future research, including mismatches between community-level needs and interests and federal flood planning mechanisms.
